content.title: Diabetic Foot Disease
content.definition: Diabetic foot disease encompasses the spectrum of foot pathology in diabetic patients including neuropathy, peripheral arterial disease, infection, and ulceration, representing a major cause of non-traumatic lower extremity amputation.

epidemiology.amputation_precursor: 85% of amputations preceded by foot ulcer

neuropathy.sensory: Loss of protective sensation (LOPS) - primary risk factor
neuropathy.motor: Intrinsic muscle atrophy, claw toe deformity, abnormal pressure distribution
neuropathy.autonomic: Decreased sweating, dry cracked skin, arteriovenous shunting

pathophysiology.peripheral_arterial_disease: 40-50% of diabetic foot ulcers have PAD component
pathophysiology.immunopathy: Impaired leukocyte function, delayed wound healing
pathophysiology.charcot_foot: Neuroarthropathy - progressive bone destruction from repeated unperceived trauma

wifi.ischemia: Based on ABI, toe pressures, TcPO2

neuropathy_screening.monofilament: 10g Semmes-Weinstein - loss of sensation indicates LOPS

infection.clinical_signs: Purulent drainage, warmth, erythema, tenderness, induration
infection.probe_to_bone: Positive test has high specificity for osteomyelitis

treatment.multidisciplinary: Podiatry, vascular surgery, infectious disease, wound care, endocrinology

offloading.critical: Total contact cast, removable walking boot, wheelchair
offloading.purpose: Reduce pressure on ulcer for healing

infection.osteomyelitis: Prolonged antibiotics (6 weeks), possible bone resection

revascularization.indication: Ischemic or neuroischemic ulcer with inadequate perfusion

amputation.indications: Non-viable tissue, uncontrollable sepsis, non-reconstructable ischemia
amputation.goal: Preserve maximum function while removing non-viable tissue

learning_objectives: Describe pathophysiology of diabetic foot disease
Apply Wagner and WIfI classification systems
Outline multidisciplinary approach to diabetic foot care
clinical_pearls: 85% of diabetic amputations preceded by foot ulcer - prevention is key
Monofilament testing identifies loss of protective sensation
Probe-to-bone test is highly specific for osteomyelitis
Toe pressure >30 mmHg and TcPO2 >30-40 mmHg needed for healing
